messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 55 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: MAJORITY-3SAT (and Related Problems) in Polynomial Time Supported by NSF CCF-1909429 and NSF CCF-1741615.

Paper Abstract: Abstract Majority-SAT (a.k.a. MAJ-SAT) is the problem of determining whether an input n𝑛n-variable formula in conjunctive normal form (CNF) has at least 2n−1superscript2𝑛12^{n-1} satisfying assignments. Majority-SAT and related problems have been studied extensively in various AI communities interested in the complexity of probabilistic planning and inference. Although Majority-SAT has been known to be PP-complete for over 40 years, the complexity of a natural variant has remained open: Majority-k𝑘kSAT, where the input CNF formula is restricted to have clause width at most k𝑘k. We prove that for every k𝑘k, Majority-k𝑘kSAT is in P; in fact, the problem can be solved in linear time (whereas the previous best-known algorithm ran in exponential time). More generally, for any positive integer k𝑘k and constant ρ∈(0,1)𝜌01\rho\in(0,1) with bounded denominator, we give an algorithm that can determine whether a given k𝑘k-CNF has at least ρ⋅2n⋅𝜌superscript2𝑛\rho\cdot 2^{n} satisfying assignments, in deterministic linear time. We find these results surprising, as many analogous problems which are hard for CNF formulas remain hard when restricted to 333-CNFs. Our algorithms have interesting positive implications for counting complexity and the complexity of inference, significantly reducing the known complexities of related problems such as E-MAJ-k𝑘kSAT and MAJ-MAJ-k𝑘kSAT. Our results immediately extend to arbitrary Boolean CSPs with constraints of arity k𝑘k. At the heart of our approach is an efficient method for solving threshold counting problems by extracting and analyzing various sunflowers found in the corresponding set system of a k𝑘k-CNF. Exploring the implications of our results, we find that the tractability of Majority-k𝑘kSAT is somewhat fragile, in intriguing ways. For the closely related GtMajority-SAT problem (where we ask whether a given formula has greater than 2n−1superscript2𝑛12^{n-1} satisfying assignments) which is also known to be 𝖯𝖯𝖯𝖯{\mathsf{PP}}-complete, we show that GtMajority-k𝑘kSAT is in P for k≤3𝑘3k\leq 3, but becomes NP-complete for k≥4𝑘4k\geq 4. We also show that for Majority-SAT on k𝑘k-CNFs with one additional clause of arbitrary width, the problem is PP-complete for k≥4𝑘4k\geq 4, is NP-hard for k=3𝑘3k=3, and remains in P for k=2𝑘2k=2. These results are counterintuitive, because the “natural” classifications of these problems would have been PP-completeness, and because there is a stark difference in the complexity of GtMajority-k𝑘kSAT and Majority-k𝑘kSAT for all k≥4𝑘4k\geq 4.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 55 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 55"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Computational Complexity - A Modern Approach",
        "Time-space tradeoffs in the counting hierarchy",
        "Phase transitions of PP-complete satisfiability problems",
        "Complexity of maximum fixed point problem in boolean networks",
        "Complexity of fixed point counting problems in boolean networks",
        "Open-world probabilistic databases",
        "The complexity of Bayesian networks specified by propositional and relational languages",
        "Deterministic APSP, Orthogonal Vectors, and more: Quickly derandomizing Razborov-Smolensky",
        "Same-decision probability: A confidence measure for threshold-based decisions",
        "Modeling and Reasoning with Bayesian Networks",
        "Approximating the permanent of graphs with large factors",
        "Fine-grained reductions from approximate counting to decision",
        "Intersection theorems for systems of sets",
        "Asynchronous p systems with active membranes",
        "Exact Exponential Algorithms",
        "Complexity of dnf minimization and isomorphism testing for monotone formulas",
        "Computational complexity of probabilistic Turing machines",
        "Computers and Intractability: A Guide to the Theory of NP-Completeness",
        "DNF sparsification and a faster deterministic counting algorithm",
        "The complexity of verifying loop-free programs as differentially private",
        "Lower bounds of tower type for szemerédis uniformity lemma",
        "A fast deterministic algorithm for formulas that have many satisfying assignments",
        "A satisfiability algorithm for AC0",
        "An efficient parameterized algorithm for m-set packing",
        "Computional complexity of Bayesian networks, July 2015",
        "Lecture notes: Computational complexity of Bayesian networks, July 2015",
        "Optimal nonmyopic value of information in graphical models - efficient algorithms and theoretical limits",
        "Optimal value of information in graphical models",
        "Most probable explanations in Bayesian networks: Complexity and tractability",
        "The computational complexity of probabilistic planning",
        "From dnf compression to sunflower theorems via regularity",
        "On deterministic approximation of DNF",
        "Dnf sparsification beyond sunflowers",
        "The complexity of MAP inference in Bayesian networks specified through logical languages",
        "A short proof of gowers’ lower bound for the regularity lemma",
        "The complexity of optimal small policies",
        "The complexity of planning with partially-observable markov decision processes",
        "Solving pppppp{}^{\\mbox{pp}}-complete problems using knowledge compilation",
        "Complexity results and approximation strategies for MAP explanations",
        "P systems with elementary active membranes: Beyond np and conp",
        "On Some Central Problems in Computational Complexity",
        "Word problems requiring exponential time(preliminary report)",
        "The polynomial-time hierarchy",
        "On approximation algorithms for #p",
        "On sets of integers containing k elements in arithmetic progression",
        "Resolution for stochastic boolean satisfiability",
        "PP is as hard as the polynomial-time hierarchy",
        "Complexity classes defined by counting quantifiers",
        "A note on approximate counting for k-DNF",
        "The complexity of enumeration and reliability problems",
        "Accidental algorthims",
        "The complexity of combinatorial problems with succinct input representation",
        "Defying hardness with a hybrid approach",
        "Breaking the 2nn{}^{\\mbox{n}} barrier for 5-coloring and 6-coloring",
        "On unapproximable versions of np-complete problems"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 55 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in MAJORITY-3SAT (and Related Problems) in Polynomial Time Supported by NSF CCF-1909429 and NSF CCF-1741615., providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
